column4: hey you guys...what exactly is this operator called  ">>"  . this is the cntext which i use it. echo "hello world" >> helloworld.txt
append
is that a bash operator?
It's bash yes.
Do you know what it does?
does bash call an external program in sbin when u use the append operator? im not exacly sure how it works, but would like to know

Well sbin programs are just programs that require root to run.  It probably has some things in bash that do file operations, those make system calls that do reads and write, those make drivers calls that spin the disk and stuff.
What is the bigger picture here?
this is actually what im trying to do, but it wont work...someone told me to use the tee utility to do this     {  sudo echo "r3d2 \n root" >> /etc/cron.allow
The reason it doesn't work is because sudo applies to echo but it does not apply to >>
I recommend: sudo nano /etc/cron.allow   and just type that stuff at the end
whats the quivalent tee command that im trying to get at?
I'm trying to look it up right now
echo 'whatever' | sudo tee /path/to/file
echo 'whatever' | sudo tee -a /path/to/file
use -a to append instead of overwriting the entire file
dc'ed?
echo 'something' | sudo tee -a /path/to/file
thanks
sure
the theme bugged out
